text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new arcade fire
album reflector grammy award-winning
famed montreal rock band considered by
many to be indie rock kingpins known for
their lavish instrumentation epic
anthemic songwriting and very emotive
vocals from front couple win butler and
regine chasanya since the mid-2000s the
band put out three full-length studio
albums that i and many other people
consider to be great
for years the band has been celebrated
as this group that just pushes things
further reaches higher just has this
massive amount of ambition and i was
pretty excited to see that playing out
into this next record of theirs
reflector an lp that looked fantastic
before its release that looked fantastic
on paper we're talking about a pretty
interesting cover here a double album
james murphy of lcd sound system and dfa
records fame taking the reins on
production for a lot of these tracks and
on the lead single the title track to
this album that was released months in
advance of this lp fantastic song a
track that embraced the tenets of disco
and is one of my favorite tracks of this
year this single and all the other
elements that i just mentioned added up
into me being super excited for this
album and overall i gotta say arcade
fire does go
in some kind of direction with this
thing i do feel like this is a more
groove oriented record for arcade fire i
think this is a slightly poppier record
for arcade fire though still very epic
and long-winded i do think there are
some really strong lyrical themes
running throughout this thing maybe a
little bit more obvious than what was
happening on the suburbs but
despite all of that i feel like this
record still fell short of my
expectations i want to start off with
the lyrics on this thing because i think
they are my favorite piece of the recipe
that arcade fire tries to pull together
you have a myriad of different song
subjects and just one liners on here
that deal with troubled love heaven
hints toward greek mythology with
orpheus and and eurodice
with songs that essentially talk about
seduction attraction and a lot like on
the suburbs there are a number of tracks
on here that sort of deal with being an
outsider being on the fringe i feel like
the first song to kind of hit with that
message as we exist a track that
lyrically to me feels like the band is
singing about being this
smaller group against this greater power
sort of having to face or having to live
in the world of
a majority that maybe morally or
ideologically they don't really agree
with and this majority is trying to
ignore them and count them out similar
themes sort of run through tracks like
joan of arc and normal person and then
there's flash bulb eyes another track on
here a lot like reflector deals with
this current vanity age or fame with
wind making reference to the old wives
tale that when you get your picture
taken it steals your soul and then
there's porno where you seem to have
this male narrator singing to a female
in a way kind of apologizing or or just
being upset about these two living in a
world where they just don't see eye to
eye with the sexual standards or what
constitutes sexy lyrically i feel like
reflector has a lot to offer on the
surface and on a more subtle level too
maybe there are a few hooks like on
songs such as you already know an
afterlife
where the lyrics are a little redundant
or overly simplistic like you already
know
or scream and shout till we work it out
but that's it it's musically where i
feel like this album sort of fails to
entertain instead of embarking on
another group of immaculately layered
songs arcade fire instead delivers a
musical jumble a stylistic hodgepodge of
different genres across the length of
reflector without much attention or care
toward whether or not all of these
sounds are flowing together well as a
record and a lot of the time i don't
even really feel like they're putting
that much care into whether or not
they're doing some of these genres
justice i've already said i like the
song reflector which obviously goes into
a bit of a disco direction and then
there is we exist which feels kind of
new wave influenced and that's a song
that i like too it's got a very
mid-paced easy going dance music beat a
warm synth bass line some shimmering
guitars it feels like a very moody
nocturnal take on the instrumental two
madonnas like a virgin but the tune of
the song is great and a lot like
reflector arcade fire manages to take
this epic anthemic feel of their music
draw it out against a very hypnotic
groove and just progress the song with
different layers of instrumentation keep
things engaging and keep things
entertaining in the process then there
is normal person where it feels like
arcade fire is is trying to play with
the idea of this being a bit of a live
recording or something thanking people
for coming out and opening the singing
line of the track asking them if they
like rock and roll music and while this
track does sound rock and roll
instrumentally there's kind of an
awkwardness to how the instrumentation
links up and it feels like there's a bit
of a tongue-in-cheek vibe to the way the
music is being played of course the song
lyrically sort of takes shots at society
and bringing that together with a weird
portrayal of a popular music genre i
can't really think of anything that is
more talking heads also the big
distorted chorus and the wailing lead
guitars as well as the the faint
distorted and kind of buried horns in
the background of this thing it's a
great track it's very well put together
even if it is kind of fuzzy and just
really over modulated which i'm sure was
intentional there's also the very heavy
dramatic and driving song
it's never over hey orpheus another
favorite of mine on here hey obvious the
groove on this thing is hypnotic it just
captures me and i'm like yes i am so
happy james murphy is doing production
on this because this is one of the
moments where his influence is is most
apparent this song and the next track on
here porno which is a bit of a subdued
track with a bit of electronic drums in
the background some synthesizers playing
a very big role yes there is a bit of a
new wave post punk minimal synth
influence here but it's very stripped
back sort of reminds me of moments from
the lcd sound system's last full-length
lp tracks like i can change or
somebody's calling me and while i think
the production is decent i'm more
enamored with the message of the song
and the tune of it more than anything
sadly that's about it for highlights for
me i only like about half of the songs
on this album and many of the other
tracks here i just find to be
half-hearted imitations of different
genres that arcade fire just wanted to
pursue on this lp for no other reason
than to do them like the song flash bulb
eyes i just don't find anything
entertaining or good about hearing wind
butler moan over this sort of strip back
dance hall beat that is kind of
underwhelming there are some echo
effects over his voice and a lot of the
instrumentation here and it's really
turned up too much to the point where
the song doesn't really read it feels
like a dub reggae nightmare and then
there's the song here comes the night
where it feels like the vocals are
really too distorted as well as the bass
and they're presented so up front and in
your face in a way where it's kind of
claustrophobic something that i feel
like works for an lcd sound system song
but doesn't do this tune too much
justice i do like the song here the
melody the piano playing is pretty
quaint but again i feel like we're
delivered an instrumental here that is
just not really a flattering portrayal
of a caribbean style of music not only
that but i feel like arcade fire
continues this faux live feel on this
track and it results in some of the
instrumentation feeling way less
explosive than it should be like the
outro where they really kind of kick up
the tempo all the instrumentation is
going incredibly fast you have these
guitars strumming very quickly and the
song here only ends up feeling like sort
of a dull drone rather than an exciting
explosion of feeling and instrumentation
you have the song you already know with
this quirky playful silly rock bass line
and this drum beat that kind of feels
like it could back a song from the
grease soundtrack groove wise the song
just feels really stiff and
kind of corny the only thing this song
is missing is a group of backup singers
going wow wow
then there's the track joan of arc which
starts off with this distorted fast punk
rock intro but then kicks into this
slowed down tempo that delivers a guitar
riff and a drum beat that feels like a
slow-motion version of a sweet song it's
got a hard rock glam rock vibe to it but
none of the joy fun or viscera the track
just feels like bad emulation with very
very little attention to musical detail
and not only that but as the song
progresses a growing problem is that it
doesn't stay interesting as the band
starts to draw this slow rock beat out
longer than it really should be awful
sound sort of an underwhelming ballad
which has some distant strings that kick
in and really sort of brings home the
title of the song but then the second
half of this track instead of being
underwhelming is sort of a slightly
insipid explosive feel good folk rock
opera that just does not vibe with me
all too well then there is super
symmetry the closer on here which i
don't even know what arcade fire was
going for on this track an incredibly
anti-climactic closer with some sequence
drums some synthesizers and i feel like
the rush of instrumentation and the
experimental last six or five minutes of
this track are more interesting than the
tune itself because winds and regimes
vocals are so buried and so comatose
that the song isn't even really
entertaining so in short i did not dig
this album as much as arcade fire's
previous lps was it what they said no
the lyrics on this thing are solid was
it the tunes necessarily only a few of
the melodies and the tunes and the songs
on here i felt were unlikable the
problem is arcade fire wanted to make
this overblown double disc album and
ended up neglecting flow in a huge way
cohesion musical cohesion between the
songs and for arcade fire the sound of
these songs was incredibly unimpressive
too even with james murphy being
credited as a producer on this album
historically the let's try to sound like
this song and let's try to sound like
this band and let's try to do that hook
that formula works really well for james
murphy but it did not work out for
arcade fire on this album there are two
new wave songs on here and a few
tropical songs on here and a few disco
oriented songs on here a bit of rock and
roll a bit of afro beat and they only
end up doing some of it justice
i'm feeling a strong five on this thing
tran position but if you've given the
cell peel listen what did you think of
it did you love it did you hate it
why
what do you think i should review next
and that's it
anthony fantano
arcade fire
reflector
forever
